statement.text: The Rule of 6s defines clinical criteria for AV fistula maturation: blood flow >600 mL/min, vein diameter >6 mm, and depth <6 mm from skin surface, typically assessed at 4-6 weeks post-creation.

explanation.intuition: The Rule of 6s provides simple, memorable criteria for determining if a fistula is ready for dialysis needle cannulation. A fistula needs enough flow to provide adequate dialysis, large enough diameter for safe cannulation, and shallow enough to be easily accessed.
explanation.key_insight: Primary fistula failure (failure to mature) occurs in 20-60% of cases, making early assessment and intervention critical. Ultrasound assessment at 4-6 weeks allows early identification of failing fistulas for salvage procedures (angioplasty, revision).
explanation.technical_details: Physical exam findings of mature fistula: palpable thrill (high-pitched vibration), soft and easily compressible body, visible outflow vein enlargement. Ultrasound criteria: measure flow at brachial artery (for upper arm) or radial artery (for forearm), measure diameter in transverse at anastomosis and outflow, measure depth from skin surface. Immature fistula: flow <500 mL/min at 4-6 weeks is concerning. Intervention options: angioplasty of stenosis, revision of anastomosis, accessory vein ligation, superficialization for depth issues.

maturation_criteria.timing: Assess at 4-6 weeks, use at 6 weeks to 3 months

physical_exam.augmentation: Visible vein enlargement with exercise/dependent arm

sources.reference: Robbin ML et al. Hemodialysis arteriovenous fistula maturity: US evaluation. Radiology. 2002;225:59-64
KDOQI Clinical Practice Guidelines for Vascular Access. Am J Kidney Dis. 2019;75(4 Suppl 2):S1-S164

learning_objectives: Apply the Rule of 6s to assess fistula maturation
Perform physical examination of AV fistula
Identify failure to mature and intervention options
clinical_pearls: The Rule of 6s: Flow >600, Diameter >6mm, Depth <6mm
Assess at 4-6 weeks to allow early salvage of failing fistulas
Failure to mature occurs in 20-60% - early intervention is key
Physical exam: Thrill at anastomosis, soft compressible body, visible outflow vein
If flow <500 mL/min at 4 weeks, fistulogram and intervention indicated
Juxta-anastomotic stenosis is the most common cause of failure to mature
